name: hake, capture by trawler and landing whole, fresh | demersal fish, fresh | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/20220/documentation

This activity represents capture and landing of  Cape hake (Merluccius capensis) by trawlers in the Southeast Atlantic, more specifically, in the EEZ of Namibia (FAO Areas 47, 48, 49 and 50). The vessels modelled in this dataset are industrial vessels with a beam of 50 m. The gear is bottom trawling. All the three modelled vessels are from Spain, but operating permanently in Namibian waters.;System boundaries and relation between activities

From the vessel use (including landing) and maintenance phases, including all upstream activities

Port operations and post-landing processing activities are beyond the system boundary.


The system is unallocated between hake landings and the by-catch
category: A:Agriculture, forestry and fishing/03:Fishing and aquaculture/031:Fishing/0311:Marine fishing

processDocumentation.timeDescription: Data corresponds to the landings by four vessels in 2011.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Cape hake (Merluccius capensis) captured and landed off the coast of Namibia in FAO Areas 47, 48, 49 and 50.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Bottom trawling, fish conservation with cooling chambers.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: The use of these data is probably also valid for other industrial hake fisheries along the southern African coast.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: 4 vessels in 2011. No feasible data on the size of the fleet.

exchanges.description: Construction of a trawler, per 1000 kg of light ship weight (LSW). Regressions based on mainly primary data were created to relate the weight of each inventory item to a trawler's LSW. The list of inventory items (granularity) contribute >95% of environmental impacts, as described in the reference publication.
